com.reactivecascade.reactive

Class Subscription<IN,OUT>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.reactivecascade.reactive.Subscription<IN,OUT>
  • Type Parameters:
    OUT -
    IN - the type of the second link in the functional chain
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    INamed, IReactiveSource<OUT>, IReactiveTarget<IN>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ReactiveValue

    public class Subscription<IN,OUT>
extends java.lang.Object
implements IReactiveTarget<IN>, IReactiveSource<OUT>
    This is the default implementation for a reactive functional chain link.

    NOTE: Because there _may_ exist a possibility of multiple fire events racing each other on different threads, it is important that the functions in the reactive chain are idempotent and stateless.

    Subscriptions are both an IReactiveTarget and IReactiveSource.

    TODO Add setFireEveryValue(true) option to queue up and fire all states one by one. If inOrderExecutor, this fire will be FIFO sequential, otherwise concurrent

    • Constructor Detail

      • Subscription

        public Subscription(java.lang.String name,
                    IReactiveSource<IN> upchainReactiveSource,
                    IThreadType threadType,
                    IActionOneR<IN,OUT> onFireAction,
                    IOnErrorAction onError)
        Create a new default implementation of a reactive functional chain link

        If there are multiple down-chain targets attached to this node, it will concurrently fire all down-chain branches.

        Parameters:
        name - the descriptive debug name of this subscription
        upchainReactiveSource -
        threadType - the default thread group on which this subscription fires
        onFireAction - Because there _may_ exist a possibility of multiple fire events racing each other on different threads, it is important that the onFireAction functions in the reactive chain are idempotent and stateless. Further analysis is needed, but be cautious.
        onError -

      • subscribeSource

        public void subscribeSource(java.lang.String reason,
                            IReactiveSource<IN> reactiveSource)
        Description copied from interface: IReactiveTarget
        Notification that an IReactiveSource will start sending updates This allows the target which is responsible for holding a strong reference to the source to prevent it from being garbage collected until all targets of a given source go out of scope and are themselves garbage collected. You may manually speed this process by calling IReactiveTarget.unsubscribeSource(String, IReactiveSource), however if you choose not to or forget to do so, it will be taken care of for you fairly soon.
        Specified by:
        subscribeSource in interface IReactiveTarget<IN>

      • unsubscribeSource

        public void unsubscribeSource(java.lang.String reason,
                              IReactiveSource<IN> reactiveSource)
        Description copied from interface: IReactiveTarget
        Notification that an IReactiveSource will no longer send updates Since this target is responsible for holding a reference to the source to keep it from being garbage collected, this target can not forget the source and, if not used elsewhere, it can be garbage collected.
        Specified by:
        unsubscribeSource in interface IReactiveTarget<IN>

                                              IActionOne<IReactiveTarget<OUT>> actionIfFound)
                                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Search downstream targets and do actionIfFound if you find the one specified
        Parameters:
        searchItem - the target to be located in the subscribed targets list
        actionIfFound - an action to perform on that target if found
        Returns:
        true if found and action performed
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • fire

        public void fire(IN in)
        Description copied from interface: IReactiveTarget
        An upchain IReactiveSource is notifying us of a new input value to process. You don't usually call the fire methods directly. They are called for you when this is an input or state change, for example by ReactiveValue.set(Object)

        Nodes within a reactive chain may choose to be stateless such as Subscription.

        Nodes at the leaf of a reactive chain will typically retain this value as state, for example (ReactiveValue).

        They may also choose to otherwise create a stateful side effect with the value received. The recommended practice is to not create such side effects except in the leaf node(s) at the end of chain branches. If you violate this rule, be warned you tend to end up with a hairy memory management and partially-completed-stateful-logic-before-exception error correction mess.

        If you would like to unlink this object when the fire operation results in an error, you must do so in an .onError() statement lower down in the chain you wish to trigger such an action.

        Specified by:
        fire in interface IReactiveTarget<IN>
        Parameters:
        in - The value from the previous link in the reactive chain.

      • fireNext

        public void fireNext(IN in)
        Description copied from interface: IReactiveTarget
        Same as IReactiveTarget.fire(Object) however this is queued LIFO for more immediate execution. You do not generally call this directly. Chains call this for you. It is called instead of IReactiveTarget.fire(Object) mid-chain to reduce work in progress and complete the task tree is an depth-first manner. This reduces the latency of individual chains once execution starts. It also decreases the peak memory load by more rapidly flushing intermediate values to the leaf node side effects of the chain.
        Specified by:
        fireNext in interface IReactiveTarget<IN>

      • subscribe

        public IReactiveSource<OUT> subscribe(IAction<OUT> action)
        Description copied from interface: IReactiveSource
        Add an onFireAction as a new branch down-chain from this node.

        It will execute on the same IThreadType as this node and may be called synchronously.

        If this onFireAction is a lambda with closure references to a surrounding Object context, subscribe the onFireAction will automatically IReactiveSource.unsubscribe(String, IReactiveTarget) when the surrounding context is garbage collected and any down-chain IReactiveTarget is garbage collected.

        Specified by:
        subscribe in interface IReactiveSource<OUT>
        Returns:

      • subscribe

        Add an onFireAction as a new branch down-chain from this node.
        Specified by:
        subscribe in interface IReactiveSource<OUT>
        Parameters:
        threadType - The onFireAction will be called asynchronously unless the this is same IThreadType as this (upchain) node in the reactive function tree.
        Returns:
